items.title: What is love – and is it all in the mind? | News | The Guardian
items.htmlTitle: What is love – and is it all in the mind? | News | The Guardian
items.snippet:
Feb 11, 2019 ... We crave romantic love like nothing else, we'll make unimaginable sacrifices for it 
and it can take us from a state of ecstasy to deepest despair.

considered close to the meaning of life, is to look at the challenges of loneliness.

comment.text: ’Tis not hereafter.
Baby don't hurt me, Don't hurt me, No more.
Dammit! That was my immediate thought and I knew out of three comments in here, someone else would have already taken it!
Beat me to it.
It will play in my brain all day long, dammit.
"... got to do with it?"
Love is a symbiotic parasitic relationship.
I don't think you can be symbiotic and parasitic at the same time, though I'm sure a biologist will tell me soon enough.
That would be marriage...
A classic symbiotic parasite example is barnacles on a whale
I don't know precisely what love is but I do know I love my wife regardless. One other thing I know is there isn't enough love in this world so when two people (or more) are lucky enough to...
Yeah, except in the huge number of cases where that love is expressed in a mutually destructive, mutually harmful relationship.
Huge? And that is not love.
good point I've seen how cheap love can be without friendship in others.
And maybe love is letting people be just what they want to be The door always must be left unlocked Howard Jones "What is Love"
That's not Haddaway.
True. But it was played at Live Aid. And at an 80s thing I went to in Devon last year where Howard Jones was the best act on the bill.
Oh dear, what a dreadful night that must have been :-(
... but a second hand emotion?
You're just bragging now - most of us make do with one....
This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our community standards. Replies may also be deleted. For more detail see our FAQs.
Haddaway (for one) could not answer this question and merely implored his beloved not to hurt him (no more). This leads one to conclude that the question is too wrapped up in emotion and the...
The strongest love I've ever felt isn't romantic but parental. It's incredibly powerful 'ends of the earth' type stuff. But that may just be me.
Not just you. And it's not only parental. When my grandchildren were born I was overjoyed to find myself feeling the same way as I'd done at my own children's births. It's absolutely the best...
I expect to have at least one grandchild in the next few years (or so they have told us). I'm even more excited about that now. Thank you.
Same for me as an Uncle. When I first saw my nephew, something imperceptible clicked in me, and intensified with his sister's birth. Their love is unconditional and pure.
